title: Domain 5.4: Summarize elements of effective security compliance.
content:
🏢 Internal

Reporting on compliance to internal stakeholders (e.g., security team, management) to ensure alignment with policies.

🌍 External

Reporting to external parties such as regulatory bodies or auditors to demonstrate compliance with relevant laws or standards.

⚖️ Consequences of Non-Compliance

💸 Fines

Financial penalties imposed for failing to meet compliance requirements—often significant.

🚫 Sanctions

Regulatory actions such as restrictions, suspension of activities, or loss of business privileges.

📉 Reputational Damage

Loss of public trust and consumer confidence can have long-lasting negative impacts.

🔒 Loss of License

Inability to operate in certain industries or regions due to failure to comply with regulatory standards.

📃 Contractual Impacts

Breaches of compliance can lead to the termination of contracts or legal actions from business partners.

🔍 Compliance Monitoring

✅ Due Diligence / Care

Ensuring vendors and partners comply with legal and regulatory obligations—vital for risk management.

✍️ Attestation and Acknowledgement

Formal acknowledgment from stakeholders (e.g., employees, contractors) confirming awareness and compliance with policies.

🏢 Internal and External

Ongoing monitoring by both internal audit teams and external auditors to track compliance and identify gaps.

🤖 Automation

Using automated tools to streamline monitoring and ensure consistent compliance reporting.

🔒 Privacy

⚖️ Legal Implications

Compliance with privacy laws that govern how data is handled, stored, and shared.

🌍 Local/Regional

Laws and regulations applicable within a specific country or region (e.g., CCPA in California).

🏢 National

Country-specific privacy laws that govern the collection, use, and sharing of data (e.g., GDPR in the EU, PIPEDA in Canada).

🌐 Global

International privacy laws that apply across multiple jurisdictions, impacting cross-border data flows (e.g., GDPR's extraterritorial scope).

🧑‍💻 Data Subject

The individual whose data is being collected, processed, or stored—data subject rights include consent, access, and correction.

👥 Controller vs. Processor

🧑‍💼 Controller

The entity that determines the purpose and means of processing personal data (e.g., the company collecting customer data).

👨‍💻 Processor

An entity that processes data on behalf of the controller (e.g., cloud providers or third-party services).

🏷️ Ownership

Clarifies who owns the data and the associated rights, such as who can access, modify, and share the data.

📊 Data Inventory and Retention

Maintaining an inventory of all data and ensuring it is retained for only as long as needed—compliant with regulatory data retention requirements.

🧹 Right to Be Forgotten

A data subject's right to request the deletion of their personal data when it is no longer necessary or if consent is withdrawn.
